headline: Miso Soup
description: This miso soup is easy to make in just 15 minutes with dashi stock, miso paste, silken tofu, and green onions for a deliciously savory appetizer.

video.description: This authentic soup takes just minutes to assemble.
video.name: Miso Soup

name: Miso Soup
recipeIngredient: 2 green onions, sliced diagonally into 1/2 inch pieces

recipeInstructions.text: Combine water and dashi granules in a medium saucepan over medium-high heat; bring to a boil. Reduce heat to medium and whisk in miso paste. Stir in tofu. Separate the layers of green onions, and add them to the soup. Simmer gently for 2 to 3 minutes before serving.

review.reviewBody: great flavors and very nutritious!

Besides being very good for you, miso soup (without the tofu and onions) is excellent to sip on through the day when on a clear liquid diet, such as the day before or after a medical procedure, such as a colonoscopy. Delicious, healthful, and satisfyingüòã

Made it...and may sound silly but it was SOOOOO GOOD and I feel super happy I can make my own miso now!!! (I've been paying a lot of restaurants for it...thinking it was difficult and expensive to make! ) yay!!!
It was a big hit. My family has a favorite sushi place that we frequent very regularly. The kids said it tasted just like theirs
I substituted baby portabellas for tofu. Quite nice.
This is a great recipe. I used chicken stock instead of water.
It turned out well, but I agree with the other reviews as it desperately needed firmer tofu.

Perfect! Made exactly as-is and added some sugar snap peas, carrots, and extra green onions.

The dashi is very important! I had to order from Amazon and made it once before it had arrived. The second attempt was much more flavorful.
This is delicious and just as good as any restaurant. Best of all, SO EASY
I am sure it will take time to get the richest broth but for a first time, it tasted like miso soup
Had to order Dashi and Miso on line, but once received it, it was so easy to make. The flavor is exactly what I know Miso Soup to taste like. Awesome.

Easy to make and tasty. Made it for my husband when he wasn‚Äôt feeling well. Wanted to give him something else instead of the chicken noodle soup he‚Äôs been drinking. The tofu is a good source of protein to fill his stomach.

This recipe is very bland, I doubled the recipe and used low sodium miso....and tripled it....it needs dried seaweed which I added. I usually add the green onion right before serving.....Personally, I really didn't like the low sodium tan miso....I will get the red miso next time.
Really delicious, reminds me of L.A.!
so yummy!! I added 1 tbsp dried seaweed and I am addicted.

I was looking to replicate the taste of restaurant miso soup at home. This does the job perfectly. That said, I prefer firm tofu to silky, but that‚Äôs a personal taste thing. Either works great in this recipe.
Tastes fresh and authentic!
tastes exactly like what I order at sushi and hibachi restaurants. seriously delicious! the only change I made is I added some nori into it.
I‚Äôve made this several times now and always make a huge batch to freeze. Made it exactly with the addition of seaweed. Love this!!
loved as is. simple and great for a cold day
Thank you for this basic recipe that was delicious and not salty! I made ramen with it with leftover meats and fresh veggies...delicious!

I added another spoon of Dashi, another 2 cups of water, a tablespoon of Sriracha, and a teaspoon of white pepper. This gave it a nice soft kick that wasn't too overpowering and not too hot on the tongue. Just the right amount of heat. 
We also added ramen noodles which made it the perfect amount of yummy and filling for us.

I will definitely make this again. My 2 year old loved it!
I doubled using 32oz vegetable broth and 32 oz water, white miso 8 Tbs, almost 1/2 c seaweed that was already cut and dried into small pieces (found at the grocery store in a bag), 1 large mushroom, 1 block of firm tofu, and only 2 Tbsp Dashi (bc I was scared it's would be strong and it was perfect).
I think it tasted as good as the restaurantmiso soup, but a million times hardier. I started an allrecipes account, just so I wouldn't lose this recipe. :)

I made this as I love miso soup. I used a dashi/miso paste & dried Wakame (seaweed) I doubled the recipe because who doesn‚Äôt want more miso soup! Lol perfect taste and no additives & the paste is good for a year in the fridge
Excellent, easy to make comfort soup on a cool autumn day.
It‚Äôs really good

Needs 6 tbsp of miso paste and 3 tsp of dashi. If you're adding seaweed add it in at the last minute or so so it doesnt get mushy. You add about 3 tbsp of warm water to the miso paste before hand and whisk it up before putting it into the pot. It'll mix in the pot a lot easier.
delish! Just like sushi restaurants!
Great basic recipe!
Loved this recipe, it was simple & delicious! I added more miso & seaweed to the recipe, It tastes better than the restaurants!
It was a 5 star meal. Thank you
Added seaweed and doubled the recipe to have leftovers for lunch the next day. With a side of white rice was just perfect!
This is an excellent recipe and stupid easy! My daughter finally learned how to make miso soup with this recipe and she couldn‚Äôt believe how easy it is to make.

We had just made a batch of light chicken broth and used two cups of broth and two cups of water instead of four cups of water. We used red miso paste and added some dry seaweed. The depth of flavor was phenomenal! We will definitely be making it again!
Tastes just like the soup you would eat at a Japanese restaurant! I had problems finding dashi granules at my local super market, but ended up finding them on amazon and they worked perfectly.

Based on ingredients on hand and others' reviews and what I had on hand, I used 3.5 T white miso paste, fish (salmon) stock in place of water, 1.5 carrots (shredded), firm tofu, and added chopped mustard greens before serving. My husband loved it and children ate it without complaint. Will definitely make again. ** We've made this recipe multiple times. Sometimes we add water, other times fish stock. We always add shredded carrot and greens.

This is a great tasting soup and very easy to make. one problem I had with it was that it separated and I had to mix it in my bowl. I made it few times and it did it every time. I also added seaweed and it was just delicious.

Went to the Asian market and asked what to get for this recipe. It turned out just like a restaurant. I used shiro miso and hondashi bonito granules I don‚Äôt know if that is a brand or a flavor, all the packaging is not in English. The kids went for it and all had multiple bowls. It seemed like too much tofu to me and I‚Äôll use half the amount next time.

Heard people on NPR talking about Miso soup. Decided to make it. I‚Äôve never tasted Miso soup at a restaurant to compare mine with theirs but I liked it and will make again. It was a great lunch paired with a salad. The challenge was finding what I needed in the Asian market without help or suggestions. I used firm tofu, Kabuto AKA red Miso and HonDashi granules.
Update- I made it again with low sodium chicken broth and love it more!

Quick easy and tasty!
I‚Äôve already made it
Again!!
I made this but added chicken, rice noodles, mishrooms and lemongrass to make thos more filling for a wonter meal. It was delicious! I use red miso for stronger flavor.
So yummy! One of my favorite soups. I did add dried seaweed as an addition.
This soup is great and so easy to make. My only disappointment is that the dashi I found at the Asian grocery store lists msg in the ingredients. I wonder if all dashi contains msg.
Everyone liked it, no complaints. Quick and easy and very tasty. I made it exactly like the recipe.
It's a very good recipe. I have a family that likes soup so I tripled the ingredient amounts. Amazing soup just like in a Japanese restaurant!
Amazing. Added probably around 5-7 tbsp yellow miso paste and needed quite a bit of salt to taste. Added ground pepper. Will probably make again :)
Perfect!
i think this is soo easy!!
I add 1 extra tbs of miso paste and it tasted great
Excellent miso! Just add some seaweed and it's just like in a good Japanese restaurant.

Yummy. Although mine tasted kind of smokey. I‚Äôm not familiar with these ingredients so I? don‚Äôt know if it was the miso or the dashi, but it was good. It was easy to make. I? added shrimp and noodles. Yum.
Genuine miso soup flavor! Didn't know tofu doesn't shrink when cooked, so only add the amount of tofu that you want.
Did not like the taste
Excellent. delicious what more is there.

Used ‚Äúbetter than chicken‚Äù paste for the broth., doubled the green onions, , used firm tofu and added a can of drained mushrooms. Got the miso paste and dashi crystals from Walmart. Great and easy soup.

Easy and so so comforting! The hardest part for me was finding the fashion granules - not at Trader Joe‚Äôs or Whole Foods (although WF has the stuff you can make your own with). I ended up finding this at an Asian market (which is probably where I should have started!) after that, easy peasy!
Have to find dashi granules. Used chicken broth. Loaded it with veggies and a few thai rice noodles. Delicious!

Loved it! Couldn't find the silk tofu at the Asian market so I just bought medium tofu and it worked fine. Next time I'm looking for natural dashi and not the msg stuff. This was excellent and tasted like the soup you would get at a high dollar sushi restraunt
Very good. I added 1 tsp grated ginger and 1 grated carrot, but otherwise followed recipe. Thanks to Amazon for the dashi granules and miso paste - nowhere to be found in a small town.

It was great! I would go for a very firm tofu next time because I wanted more texture from the tofu. The hot soup made it soften and sometimes I would slurp it down without even knowing it. Also, the dashi was a nice touch.

Came out great. I doubled the water and miso paste as the tofu and seaweed was so much. It ended up perfect soup to tofu ratio once I doubled water. I would maybe add an extra scoop of miso paste next time though.
Wonderful recipe that I've been looking for! I ordered my Dashi (Hon Dashi) and Miso paste (organic white) on Amazon in Prime pantry, it came in quick and I made the BEST miso even I've ever had.

I did not make this soup but being from Hawaii, Miso was a staple in our house. My mom made us soup when we were sick! Tofu should go in after the soup is made, right before you serve it. Fresher tasting, tofu has a tendency to harden when it is cooked!

We have made it 4 times now - it's very yummy.
Part of our regular soups now.

Perfect!! It's simple to make, full of flavor, and just like our favorite sushi restaurants serve. I ordered the dashi granuals online and used organic red miso paste, being careful not to boil it. I'd like to add seaweed in the future but I'll keep this recipe forever! Thanks for sharing it.
followed the recipe exactly as written and I don't think I'll ever buy miso soup at a restaurant again! tastes just as good or even better than restaurant miso. great recipe!!
decent miso soup- best I've made at home - 4 stars since its just miso soup...

Turned out just right! I made it in the microwave, though. I made a half recipe. Put the water and the dashi in a bowl. Microwave on high for 2 min. Add miso; microwave on 50% for 2 min. Add tofu and onion and microwave for 2 more min.
It doesn't take much time to make and it tastes fantastic! I made it with white miso and it was great. Thank you for uploading this!

I made a few alterations and additions, but my husband loves it! I took the advice of another reviewer and added 1 extra tablespoon of miso . I also added diced shallots, mushrooms and added seaweed because what is miso soup without seaweed?! If you want it to taste a little less fishy I suggest adding only 1 teaspoon of the dashi. Great recipe tho!

Since I live by myself, sometimes I don't like to cook the portion sizes in a regular recipe because it's too much. However, with miso soup, (and I have made pho as well this way) I make them larger portions and freeze it when I can. I love noodles in My Soup so I did put some rice noodles in this... Quick and easy. The only other thing I added was large slices of ginger because I love the flavor of it, but I fished it out of the broth before I eat it... I want to just a hint of the ginger flavor. I also used the firmer tofu from reading the reviews here. I have only made it the one time, but absolutely love it and definitely will make it again and possibly tweak it in some other way. At any rate, you will hear about it in these reviews. LOL. Enjoy!
Very good, easy and quick. Terrific comfort food. I added sliced fresh mushrooms. Def do-overs.
I made it and we all loved it. I made it exactly as directed, talk about a fast soup.
Love miso soup with tofu! I made it with hard tofu and diced it bigger because my children love tofu in their miso soup!Delicious!
Everybody liked it a lot but we decided to leave out the tofu next time.
Perfect measurement of ingredients! Loved it just the way it is!

My daughter and I love Japanese food. Trying to avoid eating out all of the time, I am trying to cook more at home. I decided to try this recipe, and it turned out great! My daughter said it tastes just like the Miso soup from her favorite restaurant. I used white miso and added some nori. I will definitely be making it again.

I ended up forgoing the dashi, because I wasn't able to find it at a local supermarket. I also substituted the lemon juice with rice vinegar. 

Otherwise, the recipe was fine. The green onions cute in diagonals added a special touch to the soup.

I also served a bowl of miso soup with no green onions. That was fine as well.
Loved it! Easy to make and very tasty.

Very easy. I doubled the recipe's water and tofu but only used 4 tbsp of miso and that was plenty for me. I was stupefied by the different kinds of miso and settled on an organic aka miso and it has great flavour. My kids love this soup and now I have enough to pack for their lunch tomorrow! And also added some roasted seaweed we had lying around.

This was an excellent and easy recipe for a novice miso soup maker. I tweaked it right out of the chute, because I had been scoping similar recipes. I put a little more miso in it (used white) and added a shredded carrot and some diced mushrooms. It is EXCELLENT. "Expert" Japanese chef suggested removing the soup from the heat before adding the miso. It's supposed to maintain the flavor better and keep it from separating. All I know is that I made a little batch of heaven today!

Like other reviews have stated, I prefer a firm tofu in mine. I like to add a few slices of dried shitake to mine as well and have it for breakfast with some steamed rice that has an over easy egg mixed into it.
Delicious. ..but how can it be healthy with a sodium count of 1000mg? What can I do to lower that way down?

Delicious! I made my first attempt exactly as written and it turned out even better than at my local restaurant. For Americans without an Asian market near by. My local Wegmans had everything I needed for about 6-7 bucks. and I'll be able to make a TON more with what I bought. Future versions I'll probably use a hair more miso paste because I like it salty.

My son and daughter were so excited that I could make restaurant style miso soup for them. We added fresh mushrooms to go with the tofu and green onions. So glad to add this to our family recipe book.

Made the recipe as is using the red miso paste and the silken tofu. Perfect base, tastes exactly like the restaurants. The silken tofu had a slimy texture, next time I'll do firm. Don't skip the green onion, delish :)

Made it according to recipe. Tasted great! However, next time I'll try firm tofu. The silk tofu broke up into a million pieces while I was trying to drain it. So I ended up with too much tofu and it was not diced up properly but more mushed.

I would give this more stars if possible. I have tried many Miso recipes over the last fifty years. This is by far the best I've ever made, and the only one I've made more than once. The ratio of Miso, fashion and water is perfect. The taste is awesome!

I used a readymade Miso soup packet to make it, to save time cooking. The soup was good, but next time if I use a readymade Miso soup packet I will add more tofu with the green onions. To make the soup better the next time.
Missing some seaweed and slightly fishier than expected but still quite good
Wow .. Super easy ... Delicious!!

i used my own ratios of seaweed and instead of green onions i used a whole head of baby bok choy. if you decide to do this, i recommend using an additional cup of water and 2 more teaspoons of miso paste
This soup is great. We had a family dinner and it was a hit! I need soup bowls to serve in. Anyone know where I can find white bowls made from melamine so they don't brake and I can serve my kids..

This was really good but I did make some changes. Before adding extra firm tofu, I sauteed it in some sesame oil until light golden. Also added seaweed. came out so delicious-just like a restaurants. I would def. make this again.
Easy peasy!
Very delicious soup. Me and my friends love it so much! One of my friends went as far as to buy an air freshener for his car that smells like miso soup:)
I love this soup. It's simple and quick to make. I added enoki mushrooms to the soup, just because I love enoki. This soup tastes delicious, and it's a good recipe for beginner cooks (like me).

This is my first try at Miso soup. I changed the tofu to firm as many reviewers suggested, and otherwise followed the recipe perfectly. I used organic low sodium miso paste. People were saying it was too bland or needed more miso but that was not what I found. To me, it was actually a tad bit too much miso and will add less or more water next time. (Also, I got a multi-cooker for xmas this year so I made it in there which made it even faster and easier! Thanks!

Update - Sorry. I had never used dashi and miso before and had the flavors mixed up. It was too much dashi and not enough miso. I made it a second time using 1 heaping teaspoon of dashi granules and an extra heaping tablespoon of miso. That was pretty darn close and delicious. :)

Simply great soup! Just like the stuff you find at your favorite sushi restaurants. I ordered organic white miso and MSG-free dashi granules from Amazon. I opted for organic firm tofu as that holds up better. For the much needed salt, I added soy sauce to my bowl.
